javadoc:
This singleton class seeks solutions to {@link PatternExpression}s
 
 It is called naive, because it does not perform algebraic transformations. Rather, it attempts to
 fold constants, assuming there is a single variable in the expression, modifying the goal as it
 descends toward that variable. If it finds a variable, i.e., token or context field, it encodes
 the solution, positioned in the field. If the expression is constant, it checks that the goal
 agrees. If not, an error is returned.
@TODO This whole mechanism ought to just be factored directly into {@link PatternExpression}.

Obtain an instance of the naive solver
@return the singleton instance

params.name: s

methods.comment: Retrieve the registered solver for a given subclass of PatternExpression

params.name: tcls
params.comment: the subclass to solve

methods.comment: Solve a given expression, passing hints

params.name: exp
params.comment: the expression to solve

params.name: goal
params.comment: the desired output (modulo a mask) of the expression

params.name: vals

params.name: res
params.comment: resolved subconstructors, by operand index (see method details)

throws.comment: a solution may exist, but a required symbol is missing

methods.name: solve
methods.comment:
Solve a given expression, assuming it outputs a given masked value
 
 From a simplified perspective, we need only the expression and the desired value to solve it.
 Generally speaking, the expression may have only contain a single variable, and the encoded
 result represents that single variable. It must be absorbed into the overall instruction
 and/or context encoding.
 
 More realistically, however, these expressions may depend on quite a bit of extra
 information. For example, PC-relative encodings (i.e., those involving  or
 , need to know the starting address of the resulting instruction.  must be provided to the solver by the assembler.  cannot be
 known until the instruction length is known. Thus, expressions using it always result in a
 NeedsBackfillException. The symbols, when known, are provided to the solver via the
  parameter.
 
 Expressions involving OperandValues are a little more complicated, because they
 specify an offset that affects its encoding in the instruction. To compute this offset, the
 lengths of other surrounding operands must be known. Thus, when solving a context change for
 a given constructor, its resolved subconstructors must be provided to the solver via the
  parameter.

params.name: exp
params.comment: the expression to solve

params.name: goal
params.comment: the desired output (modulo a mask) of the expression

params.name: vals
params.comment: any defined symbols (usually , and )

params.name: res
params.comment: resolved subconstructors, by operand index (see method details)

params.name: description
params.comment: a description to attached to the encoded solution

throws.comment: a solution may exist, but a required symbol is missing

methods.name: getValue
methods.comment: Attempt to fold a given expression (or sub-expression) into a single constant.

params.name: exp
params.comment: the (sub-)expression to fold

params.name: vals
params.comment: any defined symbols (usually , and )

params.name: res
params.comment:
resolved subconstructors, by operand index (see
            #solve(PatternExpression, MaskedLong, Map, Map, String))

throws.comment: it may be folded, but a required symbol is missing

methods.name: getInstructionLength
methods.comment:
Determine the length of the instruction part of the encoded solution to the given expression
 
 This is used to keep operands in their appropriate position when backfilling becomes
 applicable. Normally, the instruction length is taken from the encoding of a solution, but if
 the solution cannot be determined yet, the instruction length must still be obtained.
 
 The length can be determined by finding token fields in the expression.

params.name: exp
params.comment: the expression, presumably containing a token field

params.name: res
params.comment:
resolved subconstructors, by operand index (see
            #solve(PatternExpression, MaskedLong, Map, Map, String))

return.comment: the anticipated length, in bytes, of the instruction encoding

methods.name: valueForResolution
methods.comment: Compute the value of an expression given a (possibly-intermediate) resolution

params.name: exp
params.comment: the expression to evaluate

params.name: rc
params.comment: the resolution on which to evalute it

name: RecursiveDescentSolver
comment:
This singleton class seeks solutions to PatternExpressions
 
 It is called naive, because it does not perform algebraic transformations. Rather, it attempts to
 fold constants, assuming there is a single variable in the expression, modifying the goal as it
 descends toward that variable. If it finds a variable, i.e., token or context field, it encodes
 the solution, positioned in the field. If the expression is constant, it checks that the goal
 agrees. If not, an error is returned.
